abstracts.cdata!:
The Decoris Oil Palm Project in Liberia
            was implemented. The Bank was most helpful in exploring
            various avenues for rescuing the project from total
            collapse. The Bank also showed realism and flexibility in
            readjusting the financing categories and disbursement
            percentages in light of the project's implementation
            experience. The main strength of the Borrower's
            performance on this project was that it was quite flexible
            on many issues and was prepared to change its position even
            after holding it for a long period. The lessons learned are
            (a) Sound agronomic conditions do not necessarily ensure
            success of an agricultural project; appropriate pricing and
            marketing arrangements are also essential. (b) Smallholder
            investment is socially desirable but fraught with risks,
            particularly if the farmers lacked motivation, investments
            have a long gestation period and incentive prices offered
            are inadequate. (c) A project with a modest but successful
            beginning has a better prospect in the long-run, than one
            with an ambitious beginning which raises the risks. Without
            assurance of counterpart funding and its timely release, a
            project is doomed from the start to falter and fail. Many of
            the conceptual problems concerning this Project could,
            perhaps, have been resolved earlier if general educators had
            participated sooner in project supervision.
